prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The selected correlator configuration is optimized to provide optimal continuum sensitivity and to allow serendipitous detection of the CS(2-1) (in USB_1), HCO+(1-0)/HCN(1-0) (in LSB_1), and SiO(2-1)/H13CO(1-0) (in LSB_2), should they be bright enough for detection.

Large grains radial distribution studies in disks indicate that the grains grown beyond mm sizes are mostly concentrated within 50-100 AU from the central star (an area of 0.5-1 arcsec diameter at the Lupus distance), while the disk continuum emission is mostly within 150-200 AU (1.5-2.0 arcsec diameter). Thus the angular resolution will allow us to effectively measure the emission in the region occupied by the large grains, while the largest angular scale is large enough to encompass all the 3mm continuum emission from the disk.

This proposal is mainly focusing on continuum emission from dust grains in protoplanetary disks. Nonetheless, we would like to cover the spectral bandwidths at a spectral resolution of about 3km/s (the tipical linewidth of molecular gas in disks). Our spectral setup will conver the CS(2-1), HCO+(1-0), H13CO+(1-0), HNC(1-0), SiO(2-1). A serendipitous detection of these lines will be an important step forward for future higher spectral resolution projects to probe turbulence and chemistry in protoplanetary disks. The spectral resolution, matched to the expected line width, is perfect for serendipitous line detection.

The selected correlator configuration is optimized to provide optimal continuum sensitivity and to allow serendipitous detection of the CS(2-1) (in USB_1), HCO+(1-0)/HCN(1-0) (in LSB_1), and SiO(2-1)/H13CO(1-0) (in LSB_2), should they be bright enough for detection.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Millimeter multi-wavelength observations of protoplanetary disks allow to probe the level of grain growth in protoplanetary disks by measuring the spectral index of the continuum emission. Extensive surveys of the Taurus and Ophiuchus star forming region have not shown evidence of the evolution of grains with age: all disks seem to host a population of large grains. The few measurements available for the Lupus star forming region show tantalizing evidence for a different picture, which need to be confirmed. We propose to build on our extensive surveys of the Lupus population of protoplanetary disks and conclusively prove (or disprove) the possible evidence for a different grain population in Lupus. Our simulations show that by observing with ALMA the continuum emission at 3mm of 29 Herschel detected disks in Lupus we will have a sample of measurements large enough to conclusively settle the issue.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: 2015.1.00222.S, Disk demographics in Lupus, PI: J. Williams
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2013.1.00220.S , Disk demographics in Lupus, PI: J. Williams
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system
